Title.evidence: Personalized Pain Education and Management in Orthopaedic Trauma: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: A total of 212 patients with orthopaedic trauma were randomised

Intervention.evidence: The intervention involved personalized pain education and management by coaches, while the control group received standard written discharge instructions.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to evaluate the effect of personalized pain education and management

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the mean pain score at 12 weeks, assessed using the pain numeric rating scale.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 212 patients with orthopaedic trauma were randomised to either the intervention group (104 patients) or the control group (108 patients) between February 2021 and September 2022.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was conducted on 72 intervention and 57 control patients using a per-protocol approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The odds ratio for achieving the minimum clinically important difference in pain scores was 2.2 (95% CI 0.9 to 5.3; p = 0.08).

Harms.evidence: No differences were observed in opioid consumption or patient-reported outcomes.
